instruction: How were the extreme learning machine (ELM) and partial least squares regression (PLSR) used to optimize the spectral models for water quality parameters in sewage?
Output:
The extreme learning machine (ELM) and partial least squares regression (PLSR) were used to optimize the spectral models for water quality parameters in sewage by investigating their performance based on the sensitive spectral intervals. 

First, six kinds of sewage water samples were collected from a biological sewage treatment plant and underwent laboratory physical and chemical tests. A total of 87 samples were obtained by adding different amounts of pure water to them. The raw reflectance (R-raw) of the samples was collected using analytical spectral devices. 

The R-raw data was then processed using the standard normal variable (SNV) method to obtain the Rraw-SNV data. 

Next, the sensitive spectral intervals for each of the six water quality parameters (chemical oxygen demand (COD), biological oxygen demand (BOD), NH3-N, total dissolved substances (TDS), total hardness (TH), and total alkalinity (TA)) were selected using three different methods: gray correlation (GC), variable importance in projection (VIP), and set pair analysis (SPA). 

Finally, the performance of both ELM and PLSR was investigated based on the sensitive spectral intervals. The accuracy of the models based on the different sensitive spectral ranges selected by the three analysis methods was compared.

instruction: How did the different methods for selecting sensitive spectral ranges contribute to the accuracy of the spectral models for water quality parameters in sewage?
Output:
The different methods for selecting sensitive spectral ranges contributed to the accuracy of the spectral models for water quality parameters in sewage in different ways. 

The gray correlation (GC) method had better performance in reducing redundancy. This means that it effectively eliminated unnecessary or redundant spectral information, which helped to improve the accuracy of the spectral models. 

The variable importance in projection (VIP) method was better in information preservation. It ensured that important spectral information related to the water quality parameters was retained, which also contributed to the accuracy of the spectral models. 

The set pair analysis (SPA) method aimed to make optimal trade-offs between information preservation and redundancy reduction. It selected spectral band intervals that had a good response to the inversion parameters, while still minimizing redundancy. This approach resulted in spectral ranges that had a good balance between preserving important information and reducing noise, leading to improved accuracy of the spectral models. 

Overall, the different methods for selecting sensitive spectral ranges had varying impacts on the accuracy of the spectral models. The GC method had the highest accuracy, followed by the SPA method, and the VIP method had the lowest accuracy. These differences highlight the importance of selecting the appropriate method based on the specific water quality parameters and the desired trade-off between information preservation and redundancy reduction.
